awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of Rolling Friction in Soft-rigid Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project addresses the need for a comprehensive understanding of the nonlinear dynamics of soft rolling contact to enable prediction of instabilities arising from local frictional interference. The current state-of-knowledge regarding the modeling of soft contact dynamics is still based on a 300-year-old concept of a coefficient of friction, which was developed to represent global frictional behavior of hard rough surfaces. This concept ignores local stick-slip instabilities that represent an important source of excitation for any dynamic system involving friction. The effort will contribute to the understanding of dynamics of rolling friction in soft-rigid interfaces by abandoning the principles formulated by Amontons and Coulomb for rigid body mechanics, and by introducing the modern perception of soft adhesive contact behavior into dynamics analysis. Soft rolling motion is ubiquitous in countless engineering applications ranging from vehicle tires to power transmission in belt drives, to soft robotic grasping. If successful, the effort will significantly increase the current understanding of these systems, leading to analysis and design that will reduce energy losses, noise pollution, loss of accuracy, wear, etc. associated with dynamic effects. Successful completion of the research will also introduce an alternative way of addressing contact problems in flexible dynamics simulation, which will significantly expand the capabilities of the computational dynamics research community. The project includes outreach activities to increase participation of underrepresented groups in engineering through K-12 internship and training opportunities in the investigators' labs.

This research will explore newly-uncovered nonlinear dynamics and instabilities associated with soft rolling contact, with the objective of posing new/incorporating appropriate first-principle models based on intermolecular (adhesive) and interatomic (viscous) interactions. Without employing the concept of a friction coefficient nor the assumption of local sliding, which are both long-held and in direct conflict with experimental observations, the approach will focus on introducing a coupling of the deterministic dynamic response of the rolling system to relative contact displacements associated with a local stochastic normal (adhesive) separation and out-of-contact tangential motion. From this conceptual context will emerge the observed nonlinear dynamics and global instabilities. Results from the predictive approach will be compared to elaborated experiments involving dynamic measurements of rolling friction, observation of contact area evolutions, and examination of deformations in the near-contact zone, while using materials having different adhesive and viscous properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview
This NSF-funded project explored the mechanics of soft elastomeric rollers interacting with rigid surfaces, a phenomenon critical to various engineering applications such as manufacturing, transportation systems, and robotics. Using innovative instrumentation and advanced imaging techniques, the project uncovered the fundamental behavior of soft bodies under rolling and sliding conditions, focusing on deformation, contact instabilities, and strain distribution.

The research was conducted in three phases: in the first, a unique instrument was developed capable of studying rolling mechanics under controlled conditions. In the second, quasi-static strain fields associated with impending slip were analyzed using digital image correlation (DIC), documenting for the first time detailed strain fields associated with impending slip. In the third, a novel DIC approach was developed for analyzing dynamic rolling under convective material conditions, and high-resolution, contact region strain evolution under transient loading was experimentally measured for the first time.

Intellectual Merit
The outcomes of this project significantly advanced our understanding of rolling mechanics:

  1. Instrument Development: A novel in-situ instrument was created to measure forces, displacements, and strain fields during rolling interactions. The instrument integrated multiplane DIC and traditional force sensors, providing unparalleled insights into contact mechanics, rolling resistance, and instabilities. This breakthrough sets a foundation for future studies on dynamic rolling systems​.

  2. Quasi-Static Analysis: Using the instrument, strain fields under normal and tangential loading conditions were characterized. This phase revealed stick-slip behavior and memory effects in elastomeric rollers, contributing to a deeper understanding of contact mechanics at the threshold of gross slip. A conceptual string model was employed to explain these phenomena, validated through experiments.
  3. Dynamic DIC Innovation: A two-stage dynamic DIC methodology was developed, enabling high-resolution strain measurement in dynamically rolling systems. This approach overcame traditional challenges, such as image distortion due to large rotations and material convection. High-speed imaging captured strain evolution during transitions from static loading to dynamic steady states, highlighting transient deformation phenomena.

Broader Impacts
This research has broad implications across multiple fields:

  1. Technological Advancement: The development of the in-situ rolling instrument and dynamic DIC methodology offers tools for industries such as tire manufacturing, robotics, and aerospace to optimize rolling systems for energy efficiency and durability.

  2. Educational Contributions: The project provided training opportunities for graduate students in cutting-edge experimental mechanics, data analysis, and instrumentation design. Open-source software and methodologies developed during this work are freely available, encouraging adoption in educational and industrial settings.

  3. Sustainability and Efficiency: Insights into rolling resistance and contact instabilities have applications in reducing energy loss in transportation systems and improving material lifespans, contributing to sustainable engineering practices.

Summary of Outcomes
Over the course of the award, the project:

  • Produced archival publications documenting instrument design, quasi-static strain analysis, and dynamic rolling methods.
  • Developed open-source software tools for DIC analysis, promoting reproducibility and accessibility.
  • Generated valuable experimental data on rolling mechanics, laying the groundwork for future studies of dynamic and convective systems.

Ultimately, the findings highlight the interplay between material properties, loading conditions, and instabilities, thereby establishing a foundation for innovations in the design and optimization of rolling systems in engineering.


Last Modified: 11/30/2024
Modified by: Michael J Leamy

Project Overview

Intellectual Merit
The outcomes of this project significantly advanced our understanding of rolling mechanics:




Instrument Development: A novel in-situ instrument was created to measure forces, displacements, and strain fields during rolling interactions. High-speed imaging captured strain evolution during transitions from static loading to dynamic steady states, highlighting transient deformation phenomena.



Broader Impacts
This research has broad implications across multiple fields:




Technological Advancement: The development of the in-situ rolling instrument and dynamic DIC methodology offers tools for industries such as tire manufacturing, robotics, and aerospace to optimize rolling systems for energy efficiency and durability.




Educational Contributions: The project provided training opportunities for graduate students in cutting-edge experimental mechanics, data analysis, and instrumentation design. Open-source software and methodologies developed during this work are freely available, encouraging adoption in educational and industrial settings.




Sustainability and Efficiency: Insights into rolling resistance and contact instabilities have applications in reducing energy loss in transportation systems and improving material lifespans, contributing to sustainable engineering practices.




Summary of Outcomes
Over the course of the award, the project:

Produced archival publications documenting instrument design, quasi-static strain analysis, and dynamic rolling methods.
Developed open-source software tools for DIC analysis, promoting reproducibility and accessibility.
Generated valuable experimental data on rolling mechanics, laying the groundwork for future studies of dynamic and convective systems.



Ultimately, the findings highlight the interplay between material properties, loading conditions, and instabilities, thereby establishing a foundation for innovations in the design and optimization of rolling systems in engineering.					Last Modified: 11/30/2024
